meanings.definition: relating to or dealing with the ultimate destiny of humanity
meanings.sent1: The book discussed an eschatological view of the future.
meanings.sent2: Scholars often debate eschatological theories about the fate of mankind.
meanings.sent3: In the eschatological tale, humans discovered their true purpose in the universe.
meanings.sent4: Her paintings had an eschatological quality, hinting at profound existential questions.
meanings.sent5: The film portrayed an eschatological journey through time and space.

meanings.definition: pertaining to the end times or the final events in history
meanings.sent1: The preacher's sermon was filled with eschatological warnings.
meanings.sent2: Many religions have eschatological prophecies about the apocalypse.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked about an eschatological party at the end of the world.
meanings.sent4: The painting depicted an eschatological scene of chaos and rebirth.
meanings.sent5: The novel's climax had an eschatological intensity, capturing the end of an era.

meanings.definition: concerning beliefs or doctrines about the end of the world
meanings.sent1: The cult's eschatological teachings predicted a cataclysmic event.
meanings.sent2: Scholars study various eschatological texts to understand different perspectives.
meanings.sent3: The science fiction movie had an eschatological twist, blending futuristic technology with apocalyptic themes.
meanings.sent4: The politician's speech had an eschatological tone, warning of impending doom.
meanings.sent5: The ancient civilization's myths contained eschatological elements, reflecting their fears and hopes for the future.
